awd_titl_txt: I-Corps: Image processing software and slit lamp device for use in optometry
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is the development of a smart slit lamp. In clinical optometry, the use of slit-lamp microscopes is indispensable.  Approximately 104 million regular eye exams are performed annually using a slit lamp.  In the presence of specialized devices, the slit lamp is still widely used by optometrists across the globe for its flexibility. There are many tests that can be performed using the device, however, due to its time-consuming nature in clinical practice the number of tests performed is currently limited.  The proposed smart slit-lamp device may allow optometrists to perform multiple tests in a much shorter time and help to identify and diagnose diseases that are not currently being observed using traditional manual analysis. The proposed smart slit lamp may provide access to improved eye care and further research in the field of optometry. 

This I-Corps project is based on the development of imaging technologies and image analysis software for slit lamps used in optometry. In optometry, the slit lamp microscope is an essential device that is used to look at the interior of the human eye. Optometrists, ophthalmologists, and eye bank technicians use these microscopes regularly to observe the health of different parts of the human eye. Current slit lamps come in two forms:  analog and digital.  However, current slit lamps do not provide image analysis software or automation.  The proposed technology is designed to provide a digital slit lamp with both imaging and image analysis capabilities and more automatic operation, which may minimize human intervention and save time while making the diagnosis more objective. Preliminary work has shown that the proposed technology may provide a consistent, accurate, and objective measure that will lead to improved eye care.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project aimed to comprehensively understand the ophthalmology industry, specifically focusing on the utilization of ophthalmology imaging devices and the potential integration of artificial intelligence (AI) to enhance patient outcomes. Activities included attending industry trade shows and expos, conducting 130 interviews with ophthalmologists, optometrists, technicians, and experts, as well as additional customer discovery efforts.

The specific objective was to identify the clinical applications of slit-lamp and explore other imaging devices, their features, limitations, and clinical requirements. Key findings indicated the critical importance of slit-lamp in optometry and ophthalmology practices. Although practitioners favored its lack of autonomy, there was interest in incorporating imaging capabilities, emphasizing the need for seamless integration with electronic health record (EHR) systems.

Notably, doctors expressed a strong willingness to embrace AI-based solutions, underscoring the importance of streamlined integration into EHR systems with minimal complexity and a user-friendly learning curve.

The project encompassed engagement with various stakeholders, including optometrists, ophthalmologists, eye bank professionals, researchers, and sales executives. Both optometrists and ophthalmologists were identified and validated as the primary customer segments.

In summary, the project successfully achieved its major goals, providing a comprehensive understanding of the ophthalmology industry, exploring imaging devices, and recognizing the potential for AI integration. These insights will inform future advancements in enhancing patient outcomes within the field.
